title: American Guerrilla in the Philippines
text:
American Guerrilla in the Philippines (released as I Shall Return in the UK) is a 1950 <a href="war%20film">war film</a> directed by <a href="Fritz%20Lang">Fritz Lang</a> and starring <a href="Tyrone%20Power">Tyrone Power</a> as a U.S. Navy ensign stranded by the <a href="Japanese%20occupation%20of%20the%20Philippines">Japanese occupation of the Philippines</a> in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Based on the 1945 book of the same name by <a href="Ira%20Wolfert">Ira Wolfert</a>, it was filmed on location.
Plot.
In April 1942 in the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>, an American <a href="motor%20torpedo%20boat">motor torpedo boat</a> is destroyed by Japanese planes. The survivors, among them Ensign Chuck Palmer (Tyrone Power), make their way ashore on <a href="Cebu">Cebu</a>. Their commander orders them to split up. Chuck pairs up with Jim Mitchell (<a href="Tom%20Ewell">Tom Ewell</a>) and reaches Colonel Benson on <a href="Leyte">Leyte</a>, only to be told that he has been ordered by General <a href="Douglas%20MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a> to surrender his forces soon.
Chuck helps Jeanne Martinez (Micheline Presle), a Frenchwoman married to a Filipino planter, get medical assistance for a pregnant woman. Jeanne pleads with Chuck to stay and fight, but he buys an <a href="outrigger%20canoe">outrigger canoe</a> and recruits a crew of <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Corps">Air Corps</a> soldiers in a desperate, but unsuccessful attempt to sail to <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. When the boat founders, the crew is rescued by Miguel (Tommy Cook), a member of the <a href="Philippine%20resistance%20against%20Japan">Filipino resistance</a>. The Americans evade capture and Chuck eventually meets Jeanne again, as well as her husband Juan (Juan Torena), a secret supporter of the resistance movement.
Chuck is ordered to stay in the Philippines to help set up a network to gather intelligence on the Japanese. Later, Juan is beaten to death in front of Jeanne in an attempt to find out where the guerrillas are hiding out. Jeanne joins the resistance and is reunited with Chuck at Christmas 1943. They begin to fall in love.
After three years of fighting, Chuck, Jeanne, Jim and the rest of their band are trapped in a church by a Japanese patrol. Just when it looks as if they will be wiped out, squadrons of American planes appear overhead and explosions are heard, announcing the <a href="Battle%20of%20Leyte">liberation of the Philippines</a> is underway. The Japanese leave to face this greater threat.
Production.
US Navy Ensign <a href="Iliff%20Richardson">Iliff "Rich" Richardson</a> was the executive officer of "<a href="Motor%20Torpedo%20Boat%20PT-34">PT 34</a>". After its sinking by the Japanese, Richardson and a dozen fellow Americans attempted to sail a native <a href="outrigger">outrigger</a> to Australia, but the boat was sunk in a storm. He eventually joined the Philippine guerrilla forces, setting up a radio network to keep the various bands in touch with each other and Allied forces in Australia. After the liberation of the Philippines, Richardson dictated his memoirs to war correspondent <a href="Ira%20Wolfert">Ira Wolfert</a>, who published them in 1945 as "An American Guerilla in the Philippines". The book became a <a href="Book-of-the-Month%20Club">Book-of-the-Month Club</a> selection and was published in condensed form in the March 1945 issue of "<a href="Readers%20Digest">Readers Digest</a>".
<a href="Darryl%20F.%20Zanuck">Darryl F. Zanuck</a> of 20th Century Fox bought the film rights and had Lamar Trotti write a screenplay by August 1945. Original plans were to film the movie in <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> with <a href="Fred%20MacMurray">Fred MacMurray</a> and <a href="William%20Bendix">William Bendix</a> to be directed by <a href="Henry%20King%20%28director%29">Henry King</a>, but later plans were to star <a href="John%20Payne%20%28actor%29">John Payne</a> and <a href="Linda%20Darnell">Linda Darnell</a> to be filmed on <a href="Santa%20Catalina%20Island%2C%20California">Catalina Island</a>. The end of the war led Zanuck to shelve all films with a World War II theme.
In 1950, "American Guerrilla in the Philippines" was the first American film made on location in the Philippines in color. Fritz Lang was assigned the project, but said it was the least favorite of all his films. Though the story was well received in the Philippines, there was a protest that Filipino actors were left out of the credits, with the studio placing their names later. Zanuck, who also worked on the script and edited it, rushed the film's completion to tie in with the start of the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>.
Preservation.
The <a href="Academy%20Film%20Archive">Academy Film Archive</a> preserved "American Guerrilla in the Philippines" in 2001.
